title: Embracing ugly veg and the ugly side of poultry production to make more profitable and sustainable products - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Copenhagen-based Reduced has partnered with Caldic to develop upcycled flavor enhancers from food industry side streams, aiming to reduce food waste and enhance sustainability in food production. Their products utilize spent laying hens and discarded mushrooms to create umami flavors, thereby decreasing resource waste and cost. The collaboration aligns with growing consumer interest in sustainable and upcycled food products, leveraging innovative fermentation processes to enhance flavor and efficiency. This initiative reflects a timely response to the rising demand for sustainable food innovations in the Nordics and Baltic states.
green_innovation: TRUE: This innovation reduces food waste by upcycling side streams from the food industry, contributing to environmental sustainability through the development of sustainable flavor enhancers.
business_innovation: TRUE: The partnership between Reduced and Caldic introduces new and improved products (upcycled flavor enhancers) that significantly differ from previous methods of food production and waste management.
green_product: TRUE: The upcycled flavor enhancers are designed to minimize environmental impact by using waste materials from the food industry, thus being classified as green products.
green_process: TRUE: The fermentation techniques and processes used to convert food waste into flavor enhancers minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability through the efficient use of resources.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311942 - Spice and Extract Manufacturing; 311999 - All Other Miscellaneous Food Manufacturing; 325199 - All Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing; 311811 - Retail Bakeries
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not suggest misleading claims about the environmental benefits of the products; instead, it highlights genuine efforts to utilize waste materials in a sustainable manner.

title: TerraCycle takes recycling to a whole new level - Inhabitat
summary: TerraCycle's recycling program aims to recycle and upcycle non-recyclable items by involving businesses and communities in the collection process. The company operates Material Recovery Facilities to sort and process waste into usable materials, which are then repurposed into various products. TerraCycle also has a foundation focused on cleaning up waterways and supporting local communities impacted by pollution. The company emphasizes its sustainability efforts through zero-carbon shipping and the use of recycled materials.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is green innovation because TerraCycle's program significantly reduces environmental impact by recycling and upcycling waste, keeping it out of landfills and promoting sustainability.
business_innovation: TRUE: This is a business innovation because TerraCycle has introduced a new and improved recycling process that differs significantly from conventional recycling methods, by handling items not typically accepted in municipal programs.
green_product: TRUE: The recycled materials produced through TerraCycle's processes can be considered green products, as they are designed to minimize environmental impact and promote sustainable use.
green_process: TRUE: The recycling and upcycling processes used by TerraCycle minimize waste, conserve resources, and decrease energy consumption, qualifying them as green processes.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities, 321999 - All Other Miscellaneous Wood Product Manufacturing, 325211 - Plastics Material and Resin Manufacturing, 811310 - Commercial and Industrial Machinery and Equipment (except Automotive and Electronic) Repair and Maintenance.
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not depict greenwashing; it provides transparent information about TerraCycle's legitimate recycling efforts and their commitment to environmental sustainability without misleading claims.

title: Australia's vegetable upcycling firm launches Nutri V goodies entering the snacking space - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: Nutri V has launched Nutri V goodies, a range of puffed snacks containing two vegetable servings per pack, aimed at meeting consumer demands for healthier snack options. The firm, which previously supplied vegetable powders, is expanding into new product territories while addressing food waste by using vegetables that do not meet retail specifications. Their innovative approach focuses on incorporating more vegetables into everyday snacks and developing future products through processes like microencapsulation and fermentation. Additionally, the company is exploring scaling its business model to address vegetable waste in other regions.
green_innovation: TRUE - This innovation reduces food waste by repurposing vegetables that do not meet cosmetic standards for supermarket sales, thereby promoting sustainability and minimizing negative environmental impacts.
business_innovation: TRUE - The launch of the Nutri V goodies represents a significant shift from the company's previous product offerings of vegetable powders to a consumer-ready snack product, meeting market demands.
green_product: TRUE - Nutri V goodies are designed to be healthier snack options that incorporate vegetable servings, thus significantly reducing environmental impact and supporting better nutritional choices.
green_process: TRUE - The company employs processes that minimize waste by transforming unsellable vegetables into vegetable powders and snacks, as well as exploring sustainable production methods.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311911 - Snack Food Manufacturing, 311312 - Meat Processed from Carcasses, 322122 - Paper (except Newsprint) Mills, 424490 - Other Grocery and Related Products Merchant Wholesalers
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not suggest any misleading claims about the environmental benefits of the products; instead, it highlights clear efforts to address food waste and provide healthier snack options.

title: Unwrapping Eco-Labels: What Do They Really Mean? - U.S. News & World Report
summary: The article discusses the increasing presence and impact of eco-labels on food products, highlighting their potential to influence consumer choices towards more sustainable options. It reviews various eco-labels, such as 'Carbon Neutral Certified' and 'Regenerative Organic Certified', explaining what they signify regarding a product's environmental impact. While many consumers seek to purchase from environmentally responsible companies, the article also warns of confusion surrounding eco-labels and the risk of greenwashing in the market.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the article describes eco-labels and certifications that signify products and practices which aim to reduce environmental impact, aligning with the goals of sustainability and decarbonization.
business_innovation: TRUE, because it discusses the introduction of new eco-labels and practices that significantly differ from traditional methods, representing a process innovation within the food industry.
green_product: TRUE, because the products mentioned, such as those certified with eco-labels, are designed and manufactured to significantly reduce their environmental impact throughout their life cycle.
green_process: TRUE, because the article details processes and methodologies, such as carbon offsetting and regenerative agriculture, that minimize environmental harms and promote sustainability.

title: This engineer created a sustainable brand to upcycle waste fabric and clothes - YourStory
summary: Sujata Chatterjee launched Kolkata-based Twirl.Store to address the issue of fabric wastage and promote sustainable clothing solutions. The initiative collects unwanted clothing, donates some to those in need, and upcycles the rest into new eco-friendly products, empowering women in rural areas. The business emphasizes environmental conservation and societal impact while advocating for women's empowerment.
green_innovation: TRUE - This is green innovation because Twirl.Store reduces fabric wastage, encourages the reuse and recycling of textiles, and conserves natural resources while empowering women.
business_innovation: TRUE - This is a business innovation as Twirl.Store offers a new approach to garment waste management and creates marketable products from upcycled materials.
green_product: TRUE - The upcycled products such as bags and accessories are considered green products since they are designed to minimize environmental impact and are made from waste materials.
green_process: TRUE - The method of collecting, upcycling clothing, and employing rural women to create new products minimizes waste and promotes sustainability, qualifying as a green process.
likely_naics_codes: ['442110 - Furniture Stores', '448120 - Women’s Clothing Stores', '315240 - Women’s Cut and Sew Apparel Manufacturing', '423210 - Furniture Merchant Wholesalers']
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not suggest any misleading information about the environmental benefits of the initiative; rather, it describes a genuine commitment to sustainability and social empowerment.

title: Top 10 Expo West Food Trends for Grocers - Progressive Grocer
summary: The article covers various innovative food products showcased at the 2023 Natural Products Expo West, including mycelium steaks, gut health-focused tonics, and low-sodium salt alternatives, highlighting trends in plant-based and sustainable options. Emphasis is placed on the growth of upcycled foods and companies certifying as B Corps, promoting environmental accountability and health benefits as responses to consumer demand for sustainability. The event featured over 3,000 exhibitors and attracted significant attention for new food innovations aimed at reducing environmental impact and catering to health-conscious consumers.
green_innovation: TRUE - The products discussed in the article, such as mycelium steaks and upcycled foods, contribute to environmental sustainability goals by promoting plant-based diets, reducing food waste, and using sustainable ingredients.
business_innovation: TRUE - The introduction of new products like mycelium steaks and functional beverages demonstrates significant improvements over traditional food products, fulfilling the definition of business innovation.
green_product: TRUE - Products like mycelium steaks and low-sodium salt are designed to reduce environmental impact while providing nutritional benefits, aligning with the definition of green products.
green_process: FALSE - The article does not explicitly detail any specific manufacturing or production processes that minimize environmental impacts, focusing more on the products themselves.

title: The Age of Food Delivery: The Issue of Plastic Overuse - 국민대학교
summary: The article discusses the significant increase in plastic container use due to the rise of food delivery services during the COVID-19 pandemic, highlighting the environmental concerns associated with this trend. It suggests multi-use containers as a viable alternative and reports on consumer guilt over plastic waste. The article emphasizes the need for policy changes, responsible consumption, and consumer behavior shifts to combat plastic pollution and promote sustainability.
green_innovation: TRUE; this is green innovation as it involves the suggestion of multi-use containers, which aim to reduce plastic waste and promote environmental sustainability in food delivery.
business_innovation: TRUE; the article describes food delivery services and the introduction of multi-use containers, representing a new business process aimed at reducing environmental impact.
green_product: TRUE; multi-use containers can be considered a green product as they are designed to significantly reduce environmental impacts associated with single-use plastic containers throughout their lifecycle.
green_process: TRUE; the suggested method of using multi-use containers and a system for collecting and washing them constitutes a green process that minimizes waste and promotes sustainable practices in food delivery.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 7223 - Special Food Services, 4922 - Local Messengers and Local Delivery, 3261 - Plastics Product Manufacturing, 8114 - Personal and Household Goods Repair and Maintenance
greenwashing: FALSE; the article does not appear to promote misleading claims about environmental benefits, but rather highlights genuine efforts and suggestions for reducing plastic usage in the food delivery sector.

title: Top 10 Best Handicraft Companies In USA 2023 - Inventiva
summary: The article discusses the increasing popularity of handicraft companies in the United States in 2023, highlighting their unique, handcrafted products that cater to customer demand for quality craftsmanship. It emphasizes the significance of these companies amidst the rise of online shopping and sustainability initiatives, supporting local artisans and eco-friendly practices. The article also lists several notable handicraft companies offering a diverse range of creative goods.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the article emphasizes the importance of sustainability and eco-friendly practices within the handicraft industry, promoting products that are often handmade and locally sourced.
business_innovation: TRUE, as handicraft companies introduce unique, one-of-a-kind products and processes that differ significantly from traditional mass-produced goods, catering to consumer preferences for personalized and high-quality items.
green_product: TRUE, as the handicrafts mentioned are designed and produced in ways that often minimize environmental impact and emphasize sustainability in materials and production methods.
green_process: TRUE, since many handicraft companies use traditional, manual production methods that reduce waste, conserve resources, and can involve eco-friendly materials.
